title: Could we create dark matter? - Rolf Landua

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the matter in our universe is considered a mystery and referred to as dark matter?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because of its brightness in the visible spectrum

options.label: C
options.text: Because of its presence in the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: Because of its effects on the weather

options.label: B
options.text: They produce thousands of new particles

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By examining the trajectory of the photons

options.label: D
options.text: By examining the electrical charge of the photons

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the LHC's current research?

options.label: A
options.text: To confirm the existence of the Higgs boson

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To study the properties of quarks and gluons

title: The rise and fall of the Berlin Wall - Konrad H. Jarausch

options.text: The Allies disagreed on the location of the German capital.

options.label: D

title: Why a total solar eclipse is such a big deal

multiple-choice.question: What is a solar eclipse?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: When the moon's shadow falls on the surface of the Earth

options.label: C
options.text: When the sun's shadow falls on the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: When the Earth's shadow falls on the sun

multiple-choice.question: What are the two sections of the shadow during an eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: When the moon partially covers the sun

options.label: B
options.text: When the moon fully covers the sun, revealing the sun's outer atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: When the Earth's shadow falls on the moon

options.label: D
options.text: When the sun's shadow falls on the Earth

multiple-choice.question: Why don't we get eclipses every month?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: The moon's orbit is not in line with the Earth's orbit

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere scatters the longer, redder wavelengths of light

options.label: B
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere scatters the shorter, bluer wavelengths of light

options.label: C
options.text: The moon's atmosphere scatters the longer, redder wavelengths of light

options.label: D
options.text: The sun's atmosphere scatters the shorter, bluer wavelengths of light

multiple-choice.question: How often does the Earth get a total solar eclipse on average?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Totality is visible from anywhere on Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Totality is visible from the entire night side of the Earth

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The moon is moving further away from the Earth

options.label: C
options.text: The sun is moving closer to the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: The sun is moving further away from the Earth

options.label: C
options.text: Mass and charge of a particle

options.label: D
options.text: Spin and velocity of a particle

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The spin of the electron is changed

options.label: D
options.text: The energy of the electron is increased

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.text: A teleported object transports across space like tangible matter

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A teleported object does a little of both, transporting and transmitting across space

options.label: D

title: How do drugs affect the brain? - Sara Garofalo

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor that determines how a drug affects the way we physically feel, think, and behave?

options.label: B
options.text: The chemical composition of the drug

options.label: D
options.text: How a drug alters the communication between cells in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is the slowest method of administering a drug?
What is the blood-brain barrier, and what is its primary function?

options.label: A
options.text: A network of neurons that separates the brain from the nervous system

options.label: B
options.text: A barrier that separates blood from the nervous system to keep potentially dangerous substances out

options.label: C
options.text: A structure that allows the exchange of electrochemical signals between neurons

options.label: D
options.text: A mechanism that degrades or reabsorbs neurotransmitters

multiple-choice.question: What are the two primary ways that neurotransmitters work in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They can either stimulate the growth of new neurons or repair damaged ones

options.label: B
options.text: They can either inhibit the receiving neuron or excite it

options.label: C
options.text: They can either regulate emotions or cognition

options.label: D
options.text: They can either increase or decrease the amount of dopamine in the brain

options.label: B
options.text: They stop the reabsorption of serotonin

options.label: C
options.text: They block the release of dopamine

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary effect of tranquilizers, such as benzodiazepines, on the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They increase the production of dopamine

options.label: B
options.text: They raise levels of serotonin and noradrenaline

options.label: C
options.text: They increase the production of GABA to inhibit neural activity

options.label: D
options.text: They block the reuptake of dopamine and serotonin

multiple-choice.question: How does crystal meth, an amphetamine, affect the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It induces a long-lasting release of dopamine and activates noradrenaline receptors

options.label: B
options.text: It blocks the reuptake of dopamine and serotonin

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the production of GABA

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the release of serotonin

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary effect of hallucinogenic drugs, such as LSD, on the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They increase the production of dopamine

options.label: B
options.text: They block the reuptake of dopamine and serotonin

options.label: C
options.text: They block the release of serotonin and impact neural circuits involved in perception and learning

multiple-choice.question: Why are some drugs highly controlled and often illegal?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have the power to alter the brain's chemistry and repeated use can permanently rewire neural networks

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have negative side effects

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not effective medicines

options.label: A
options.text: The development of new recreational drugs

options.label: B
options.text: A greater understanding of the neural networks that support our ability to think and learn

options.label: C
options.text: The creation of more effective medicines to treat medical problems

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in the use of illicit drugs

options.label: B
options.text: Capillary action is the repulsion between liquids and surfaces, and it was proposed to be used to push water down a tube

options.label: C
options.text: Capillary action is the attraction between solids and surfaces, and it was proposed to be used to lift a ball up a ramp

options.label: D
